qas.question: Who did he have to thank for his ability to come back to Alexandria in 345?
Were the people glad to have him home?
In what writing did he recount his time in exiles?
Did the new emperor agree or disagree with the Arians?
Who was not thanked for letting him back in Alexandria?

plausible_answers.text: Constans used his influence to allow Athanasius to return to Alexandria

qas.question: When did the uncivil war happen?

context: After the death of the replacement bishop Gregory in 345, <a0_0><b5_0><b6_0>Constans<b5_0/><a0_0/> used his influence to allow Athanasius to return to Alexandria<b6_0/> in October 345, amidst the <a1_0>enthusiastic demonstrations<a1_0/> of the populace. This began a "golden decade" of peace and prosperity, during which time Athanasius assembled several documents relating to his exiles and returns from exile in the <a2_0>Apology Against the Arians<a2_0/>. However, upon Constans's death in <b7_0><b8_0>350<b8_0/><b7_0/>, another <a3_0>civil war<a3_0/> broke out, which left <a4_0>pro-Arian<a4_0/> Constantius as sole emperor. An Alexandria local council in 350 replaced (or reaffirmed) Athanasius in his see.
